sweet & savoury mushroom scones~ this easy and quick snack made with our favourite mushrooms is definitely a pleaser. we love having them with cream cheese, random toppings and even on its own. mama also made them petite so it's easy to pack them along as mini treats for the kids' outings! 
.
ingredients:
200 gram swiss brown mushrooms, chopped 
220 gram all purpose flour
20 gram sugar
6 gram baking powder
1/2 teaspoon salt
1 teaspoon 
55 gram cold butter, cut into small cubes
25 gram beaten egg
approx. 100 ml milk 
.
method:
in a pan, sauté chopped mushrooms with some butter till slightly brown and set aside to cool
combine flour, sugar, baking powder, salt and in a bowl
rub in butter cubes with fingers until the mixture resembles breadcrumbs before adding in the sautéed mushrooms 
add in beaten egg and milk, and mix with a spatula until just combined with no dry flour remaining (add more milk if required)
turn the dough out onto a floured surface and sprinkle some flour on top
pat the dough down lightly to about 3 cm thick and cut straight down with a round cutter without twisting it
gather the loose piece of dough into a ball and pat down again to cut out more
brush the top of the scones with egg and bake in a preheated oven for 15-20 minutes at 180 °c till golden brown

honey-lemon vinaigrette: 

 making honey is incredibly resource intensive for a honey bee colony. a worker bee makes 1/12 of a teaspoon of honey during its entire lifetime. it has to consume honey in order to make honey.

knowing how hard bees work, i strive to use every last drop of honey. when lemon juice is mixed with honey, the acidity of the lemon dilutes the viscous honey, making it possible to get every last sweet drop!

so when i have almost used all of the honey in a jar, i know it is the ideal time to make honey-lemon vinaigrette ~ in the honey jar itself.

ingredients:
 1-2 tablespoon of honey
 2-3 tablespoon of fresh-squeezed lemon juice from 2 lemons

 2 teaspoon whole grain, old style mustard (optional)
 1/2 teaspoon sea salt
 freshly ground pepper
1/3 cup extra-virgin olive oil
 1/3 cup extra-virgin olive oiltional)

 squeeze 2 lemons with seeds removed
 pour lemon juice in honey jar and shake with lid on vigorously to mix the lemon and honey. this will help integrate the honey into the vinaigrette as you add ingredients.
 add garlic, mustard, sea salt, and ground pepper and shake with lid on vigorously again.
 when the honey and other ingredients are well-integrated, add olive oil and leaves of fresh thyme. shake with lid on again. adjust salt and pepper to taste.

probably one of the simplest indian dishes you can cook and healthy and cheap too! ⁠

lentils are high in fibre, and complex carbohydrates, while low in fat and calories. their high protein, gluten free whicht makes them a perfect option for those on a low carb diet. ⁠

1 cup red split lentils ⁠

1 teaspoon. turmeric ⁠
1 teaspoon. paprika ⁠
2 tablespoon. garlic and ginger paste⁠

salt to taste⁠
green chillies, 2 small ones chopped (optional)⁠

 a slice of happiness: spiced plum custard cake

salmon, butternut squash, sweet potato and kale bake || 

something easy and super healthy to make and tastes sooo good! managed to put this together for my hubby’s birthday this is something that i will keep making because it’s just so convenient, and can try and add in more veggies too! 

ingredients:
2-4 salmon piece 
1 medium butternut squash (cubed)
1 medium sweet potato (cubes)
kale (shredded/chopped - i just bought a bag that was already shredded )
1 tablespoon rice bran oil (or oil of your choice)
1 teaspoon cajun
1 teaspoon paprika
1 teaspoon garlic powder
1/2 teaspoon turmeric 
1/2 teaspoon himalayan salt
1/2 teaspoon black ground pepper
1/4 teaspoon rosemary (for the salmon) 

method:
1 ) preheat the oven to 200 c and line a big oven dish/tray with baking paper
2 ) mix oil and all spices together (apart from the rosemary) in a bowl and toss thoroughly with the butternut squash and sweet potato. place on the baking tray and bake for 20-25 minutes until soft
3 ) take the tray out of the oven, turn over the butternut squash and sweet potato and add the kale. place the salmon piece on top and season with salt, pepper and rosemary 
4 ) place the tray back in the oven to cook for another 20-25 minutes or until the salmon is cooked through (it should be flaky and check that it is piping hot inside!)
5 ) serve immediately. feel free to have this with some extra salad 
6 ) enjoy!

​ingredients:
​
serves 2 
200 gram dried pasta
1 tablespoon salt
70 gram crusty bread
2 tablespoon olive oil
30 gram butter
70 gram hazelnuts
1 garlic clove cracked open
150 gram asparagus
150 gram taleggio cheese
1 handful of parsley chopped
​
here’s how:
​
cook the pasta in a large pan of salted, boiling water for 9-10 minutes.
meanwhile snap the asparagus in half and where it naturally breaks that’s where it's tender and put to one side.
chop the bread up into small piece and place on a non-stick baking tray.
pour over a drizzle of oil and bake in a pre-heated oven at 170 c for 10 minutes or just until crisp.
meanwhile melt the butter in a large pan with the cracked garlic clove.
chop the hazelnuts into chunks and add to the pan with the butter and garlic.
lift out a ladle of pasta water and add to the butter with a little black pepper.
this will make an emulsion-style sauce.
lay the asparagus into the sauce and pop the lid onto the pan to speed up the cooking process without evaporating the sauce too much.
when the pasta has cooked for 9 minutes, lift out of the water and add to the pan.
stir together and top with chopped parsley and diced cheese.
finish with a drizzle of extra virgin olive oil and scatter over the breadcrumbs.
